Google Gemini AI assistant (abused as automation tool)

timeline.event: PromptSpy malware first observed in the wild targeting Argentine users via fake MorganArg banking app
ESET researchers identify novel use of Google Gemini API within the malware's runtime execution flow
ESET completes analysis confirming PromptSpy as the first Android malware to weaponize generative AI at runtime
ESET publishes full technical analysis on WeLiveSecurity, disclosing PromptSpy capabilities and IOCs
Google acknowledges the abuse of Gemini API and begins reviewing detection mechanisms

simple_summary.what_happened: ESET security researchers discovered a groundbreaking Android malware called PromptSpy that represents a dangerous first: it uses Google's Gemini generative AI assistant at runtime to automate malicious tasks on infected phones. The malware disguises itself as a fake JPMorgan Chase banking app called MorganArg, targeting users in Argentina. Once installed, PromptSpy uses VNC (remote desktop) capabilities to take full control of the device, captures lockscreen PINs, records the screen, and most notably, leverages Google Gemini's AI to intelligently navigate the phone's user interface to maintain persistence and evade removal. This is the first documented case of malware using a commercial generative AI service as part of its core attack chain.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Android users in Argentina who may have downloaded the fake MorganArg banking application are the primary targets. However, the technique of weaponizing generative AI at runtime represents a threat to all Android users globally, as the approach can be adapted to target any region or banking institution. Organizations that allow employees to use personal Android devices for work (BYOD) face additional risk of corporate credential theft. Google Gemini users are indirectly affected as the AI service is being abused without their knowledge.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: The attackers distribute a fake JPMorgan Chase banking app called MorganArg through the malicious domain mgardownload[.]com, tricking Argentine users into sideloading the APK outside of Google Play Store. Step 2: Once installed, the malware requests Accessibility Service permissions, which grants it the ability to observe and interact with all apps and UI elements on the device. Step 3: PromptSpy activates its VNC module to establish a remote desktop connection back to the attacker's command-and-control server at 54.67.2[.]84, giving the attacker real-time visual access to the victim's screen. Step 4: The malware captures the device lockscreen PIN by overlaying a fake unlock screen, and continuously records the user's screen activity including banking sessions and private messages. Step 5: In a novel technique, PromptSpy sends prompts to the Google Gemini AI assistant asking it to navigate the device's recent apps menu, settings, and notification panels to keep the malware running in the foreground and prevent the user or the operating system from killing the malicious process, achieving AI-powered persistence.
what_you_should_do: Never sideload Android APKs from unknown sources; only install apps from the official Google Play Store and verify the developer identity
Check your installed apps for any application named MorganArg or claiming to be a JPMorgan Chase app not published by JPMorgan Chase & Co.
Review Accessibility Service permissions on your Android device (Settings > Accessibility) and revoke access for any unfamiliar or suspicious applications
Block the known malicious domains mgardownload[.]com and m-mgarg[.]com and C2 IP 54.67.2[.]84 on your network security devices
Enable Google Play Protect and ensure it is actively scanning your device for harmful applications
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: PromptSpy represents a paradigm shift in mobile malware by demonstrating that attackers can weaponize commercial generative AI services to make their malware smarter and more resilient. Traditional malware uses hardcoded logic that defenders can predict and block, but by leveraging Gemini AI for dynamic UI navigation, PromptSpy can adapt its behavior in real-time based on the device's current state. This makes it significantly harder to detect and remove. The technique is highly replicable and will almost certainly be adopted by other threat actors, potentially spawning a new generation of AI-enhanced malware. Combined with its banking trojan capabilities including VNC remote access and PIN capture, PromptSpy poses an immediate financial threat to victims and a strategic threat to the entire mobile security ecosystem.

tactics.description: PromptSpy disguises itself as MorganArg, a fake JPMorgan Chase banking app, to trick users into installing the malicious APK from a third-party download site
Uses Google Gemini AI to dynamically navigate the Android UI, keeping the malware in the foreground and preventing the OS from killing the process - a novel AI-driven persistence mechanism
Requests and abuses Android Accessibility Services to gain elevated control over all UI elements and applications on the device
Captures the device lockscreen PIN through a fake overlay screen and records on-screen keyboard input during banking sessions
Continuously records the device screen via VNC module, capturing banking credentials, messages, and all visual content displayed to the user
Establishes VNC remote desktop connection to C2 server at 54.67.2[.]84 for real-time device control and data exfiltration
Leverages Gemini AI to interact with system settings and notification panels to dismiss security warnings and hide evidence of the malware's presence

detection_guidance.summary: Detection focuses on identifying the fake MorganArg application, monitoring for suspicious Accessibility Service usage, detecting VNC remote access connections to known C2 infrastructure, and identifying unusual Google Gemini API calls originating from non-user-initiated contexts.

log_sources.description: Monitor for installation of apps named MorganArg or apps with package names associated with the PromptSpy campaign; check for apps requesting Accessibility Service permissions
Monitor for VNC connections to C2 IP 54.67.2[.]84 and DNS queries to mgardownload[.]com and m-mgarg[.]com domains
Audit which applications have Accessibility Service permissions enabled; newly granted permissions to unknown apps are high-priority indicators
Monitor for unusual Gemini API usage patterns that may indicate automated prompting from malware rather than legitimate user interaction

what_to_look_for.description: The presence of an app named MorganArg or claiming to be a JPMorgan Chase app that was not installed from Google Play Store

what_to_look_for.indicator: VNC connections to known C2 infrastructure
what_to_look_for.description: Outbound VNC traffic from Android devices to the PromptSpy command-and-control server

what_to_look_for.indicator: DNS queries to malicious distribution domains
what_to_look_for.description: DNS resolution attempts for PromptSpy distribution and C2 domains
A sideloaded application requesting or being granted Accessibility Service permissions, particularly one mimicking a banking app
Rapid or programmatic Gemini API calls that do not match normal user interaction patterns, potentially indicating malware-driven AI automation

immediate_actions.description: Immediately block the C2 IP address 54.67.2[.]84 and domains mgardownload[.]com and m-mgarg[.]com on your firewalls, DNS sinkholes, and web proxies to prevent malware communication and new infections.

immediate_actions.action: Scan for MorganArg app on managed devices
immediate_actions.description: Use your MDM solution to scan all managed Android devices for the presence of any application named MorganArg or matching known PromptSpy package names and SHA-1 hashes.
Review all Android devices for applications with Accessibility Service permissions enabled. Any unfamiliar or recently added application with this permission should be investigated immediately.
immediate_actions.command: adb shell settings get secure enabled_accessibility_services

immediate_actions.description: Ensure that Android device policies prevent installation of APKs from unknown sources. Configure MDM to block sideloading and restrict app installation to Google Play Store only.

immediate_actions.action: Brief security awareness teams on AI-powered malware
immediate_actions.description: Notify your security operations team about this new class of AI-enhanced malware. Update threat models to account for the possibility that malware can use commercial AI services to dynamically adapt its behavior on infected devices.
